instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Looking for help here.
Works perfect until lid gets closed upon which I guess an smc reset keeps happening. When the lid is closed for a short while you hear the chime and it reboots and either comes back on or stays off. Then power button to get going again. Sometimes I have to do another smc reset because it comes on with no backlight. This doesn't worry me however because it only happens when the first problem happens. 

I have swapped I/o board and trackpad. <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is 3.4v when open and 0 when closed. I have changed <RESISTOR>R5171</RESISTOR> as well. 
Totally stuck as to why when closing lid it decides to restart. So thanks in advance for the time spent helping.

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
[solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: have a look at the hall effect sensor for corrosion, that can cause messed up readings

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Hall sensor issue will never cause a reboot.

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
[solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Problem solved. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> line was not being created.

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: It would be stone cold dead without that rail......

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Must of been the ic because I changed as well and there was small corrosion around pin 17 and <RESISTOR>R7202</RESISTOR> had a hole in it. 
The problem 100% was fixed after doing so anyway
